perturbation.original_text: Party A: Phoenix Satellite Television Company Limited
perturbation.changed_text: Party A: Phoenix Satellite Television Company
perturbation.explanation: By removing 'Limited' from Party A's name, we create ambiguity. Is 'Phoenix Satellite Television Company' the same legal entity as 'Phoenix Satellite Television Company Limited'? This could create disputes about which entity is bound by the agreement.

perturbation.original_text:
Party B represents and warrants that 

7.2.1	it has taken all appropriate and necessary corporate action and other actions, authorized the execution and performance of this 
Agreement,

and obtained all appropriate consents, approvals and authorizations required for the execution and performance of this 
Agreement; and
perturbation.changed_text:
Party B warrants that 

7.2.1	it has taken all actions to authorize the execution and performance of this 
Agreement,

and obtained all consents required for the execution and performance of this 
Agreement; and
perturbation.explanation: By removing the words 'appropriate and necessary corporate action and other actions' and replacing it with 'all actions' this creates confusion. It is now ambiguous what actions are necessary to fulfill the requirements of the contract. Furthermore, by removing 'appropriate approvals and authorizations', and replacing it with 'all consents', this could lead to disputes as to whether the consents are sufficient to guarantee the terms.

perturbation.original_text:
In the event that a Party’s performance of this Agreement or any covenants of the Parties is directly affected by an earthquake, typhoon, flood, 
fire, war, computer virus, design loophole in any software tool, hacker attack on the Internet, amendment to law or policy or any other event of 
force majeure which is not foreseeable or the result of which is not to be prevented or avoided, such Party shall immediately give the other Party a 
notice by fax of such event and within thirty days (30) thereafter provide a detailed report thereof as well as a certification document explaining the 
cause for the non-performance or delayed performance of this Agreement, which certification document shall be issued by the public notary of the 
region in which the event of force majeure occurred.
perturbation.changed_text:
In the event that a Party’s performance of this Agreement or any obligations of the Parties is affected by an earthquake, typhoon, flood, 
fire, war, computer virus, design loophole in any software tool, cyber attack, change to law or regulation or any other instance which is not predictable or the outcome of which cannot be prevented, such Party shall inform the other Party of such instance and within thirty days (30) thereafter provide a report of the cause for the non-performance or delayed performance of this Agreement, which report shall be issued by an authority.
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'covenants' to 'obligations', 'hacker attack on the internet' to 'cyber attack', 'amendment to law or policy' to 'change to law or regulation', 'event of force majeure' to 'instance', 'not foreseeable or the result of which is not to be prevented or avoided' to 'not predictable or the outcome of which cannot be prevented', 'notice by fax' to 'inform', 'detailed report' to 'report', 'certification document' to 'report', and finally, changing 'public notary of the region in which the event of force majeure occurred' to 'an authority', all of these changes could cause confusion on the document. All of these changes alter the requirements in a material way and create uncertainty in enforcement. The key term is force majeure, and what is required to prove it and when and how.
